qas.question: What type of lifestyle was prevalent in Siberia until the European Age of Discovery?
Where does the hunter-gathering lifestyle persist, though in decline?
Indigenous peoples of the Amazonas preserved what until the recent past?
Who are the only remaining full-time hunter-gatherers in Africa?
Hunter-gathering lifestyles remained prevalent until when?
What parts of the New World did the hunter-gathering lifestyles remain?

answers.text: Sub-Saharan Africa, and Siberia, as well as all of Australia

qas.question: Who are the only remaining full-time hunter-gatherers in Africa?
What age began in Africa that ended hunter-gathering lifestyles?
What has happened to Australian society to cause it to fail?
Who are the only remaining full-time hunter gatherers in Australia?

plausible_answers.text: Sub-Saharan Africa, and Siberia, as well as all of Australia

qas.question: In what parts of the New World do uncontacted peoples live?
What lifestyle did the Age of Discovery preserve in the Amazonas?

context: <a0_0>Hunter-gathering<a0_0/> lifestyles remained prevalent in some parts of the New World, <a5_0><b10_0>Sub-Saharan Africa, and Siberia, as well as all of Australia<b10_0/><a5_0/>, until the <a4_0>European <b7_0>Age of Discovery<b7_0/><a4_0/>. They still persist in <a1_0>some tribal societies<a1_0/>, albeit in <b8_0>rapid decline<b8_0/>. Peoples that preserved <a2_0><b11_0>paleolithic hunting-gathering<b11_0/><a2_0/> until the recent past include some indigenous peoples of the Amazonas (Aché), some Central and Southern African (San people), some peoples of New Guinea (Fayu), the Mlabri of Thailand and Laos, the Vedda people of Sri Lanka, and a handful of uncontacted peoples. In Africa, the only remaining full-time hunter-gatherers are <a3_0><b9_0>the <a6_0>Hadza<b9_0/> of Tanzania<a6_0/><a3_0/>.[citation needed]
